ImageData.LabelName: b) Cancer in one lymph node in the pelvis
a) Layer of fat around bladder
b) Cancer in one lymph node in the pelvis
a) Layer of fat around bladder

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Added a label for the uterus in the female figure, added a bit of shading behind the prostate label, and made the lymph nodes a bit more prominent in the female figure on the R side so they are similar to the lymph nodes in the male version
Diversity updates: Changed image to a two-panel image and added a female figure (as the right panel); updated skin tone for both figures to FP V; centered the title above the two panels
Made cancer spot darker per expert reviewer

Added a label for Prostate; Moved the a) up next to the “Layer of fat around the bladder” label; Put a bracket on each side of the common iliac arteries, going from where they join the main artery at the top to where they branch into the external iliac arteries at the bottom (right where the ureter crosses the blood vessels)

Added label for Common iliac arteries; made the node with cancer the one nearest the ureter and took cancer out of all of the other nodes; made all of the cancer-negative nodes less “shiny”; and added a ) around the small a.
Image revisions made per AJCC updates (8th edition)
Made the cancer spot in the main figure “match” the cancer in the inset (more orangy, bumpy).

Removed outer pink layer in the inset; changed Fat label to say "Fat around the bladder" and put line from the label so that it points to the paravesical fat in addition to the fat layer in the inset; made cancer spot darker to distinguish it from the fat.

Removed cancer spots on the main image except for the one inside the little box; made the cancer spot only go up into the Fat layer in the inset and on the main figure in the little box; removed the thin yellow line in the area where the perivesical fat is, and made the fat go up around the edges of the bladder at the top where the peritoneal layer is; removed the little rings that look like cherios on the right and left side of the bladder in the main figure; and added a line from the label Fat to the perivesical fat in the main figure.

Removed Peritoneum label; removed all lines from labels to little box on the main figure; added a line going from the top right and bottom right corners of little box on main figure to the top and bottom left corners on the inset; made cancer in little box match the cancer in the inset; removed the cancer spots "floating" in the white space in the inset.

Changed labels from Serosa to Fat, Lamina propria to Connective tissue, and Urothelium to Inner lining. Added color to show all the different layers in the inset. Made cancer spot in inset wider so overall spot looks bigger and not tall/skinny. Removed cancer-looking spot next to the ureter on the bladder image.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Two-panel drawing showing stage IIIA bladder cancer in a male (left panel) and a female (right panel); both panels show cancer in the bladder and in (a) the layer of fat around the bladder and (b) one lymph node in the pelvis. Also shown are the right and left common iliac arteries, the prostate (left panel), and the uterus (right panel).

Two-panel drawing showing stage IIIA bladder cancer in a male (left panel) and a female (right panel); both panels show cancer in the bladder and in (a) the layer of fat around the bladder and (b) one lymph node in the pelvis. Also shown are the right and left common iliac arteries, the prostate (left panel), and the uterus (right panel).

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIIA bladder cancer. Cancer (a) has grown all the way through the bladder muscles and bladder wall into the layer of fat around the bladder and may have spread to the prostate and/or seminal vesicles in men or the uterus and/or vagina in women but has not spread to lymph nodes; or (b) has spread to one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac arteries.

Stage IIIA bladder cancer. Cancer (a) has grown all the way through the bladder muscles and bladder wall into the layer of fat around the bladder and may have spread to the prostate and/or seminal vesicles in men or the uterus and/or vagina in women but has not spread to lymph nodes; or (b) has spread to one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac arteries.
